Early Years SEND (0 to 5)

  3. Early Years SEND (0 to 5)

If you are worried about your baby, toddler or young child's development, help is available from birth. The earlier extra needs are identified, the sooner the right support can begin.

You know your child best

If something does not feel right, trust your instincts. Every child develops at their own pace, but if you have concerns about your child's development, talking to someone early is always the right thing to do.

You will not be wasting anyone's time. Professionals would always rather hear from you sooner than later.

Who can spot that your child might need extra help

Concerns about a young child's development can come from many people:

  • You — parents and carers often notice things first
  • Health visitors — through routine developmental checks
  • Your GP or paediatrician
  • Nursery or childminder — staff at early years settings
  • Children's Centre staff

What to do if you are worried

Talk to your health visitor or GP

They can check your child's development and refer to specialists if needed. Health visitors carry out routine checks at key ages, but you can ask for an extra appointment at any time.

Speak to your child's nursery or childminder

Every early years setting must follow the SEND Code of Practice. They should have a named person responsible for SEND coordination. Ask to speak to them about your concerns.

Request an EHC needs assessment

If your child has significant needs, you can request an EHC needs assessment from birth. You do not have to wait until your child starts school. The 20-week timescale applies from the date of your request.

Find out how to request an assessment

SEND support in early years settings

Nurseries, pre-schools and childminders must use a graduated approach to identify and support children with SEND. This means:

  • observing your child and assessing their needs
  • planning support with clear targets
  • putting that support in place
  • reviewing progress and adjusting as needed

If your child needs more specialist help, the setting can bring in outside professionals such as speech and language therapists or educational psychologists.

Disability Access Fund

If your child is aged 3 or 4, has a disability and receives Disability Living Allowance (DLA), their early years provider may be able to get extra funding called the Disability Access Fund (DAF). This money helps the setting make adjustments to support your child better.

Ask your child's nursery or pre-school whether they have applied for the DAF.

Getting ready for school

If your child has an EHC plan before they start school, the annual review must take place by 31 March in the year before school entry. This review will help plan the transition and make sure the right support is in place from day one.

If your child does not have an EHC plan but has SEND, speak to the school's SENDCo early so they can plan support before your child starts.

Early help matters

EHC needs assessments can be requested from birth. You do not need to wait until your child starts school.
